They came together approximately three years ago because of the necessity of gathering working capital that permits them to begin or improve their businesses and increase their income. This allows a better quality of life for them and their families..

Now, they all have their own businesses like the sale of food, a neighborhood shop, the sale of cosmetics, the sale of blankets, the sale of footwear, the sale of cassava, and the making of sheepskin jackets. They need a loan for the purchase of merchandise. They also like to share. As a result they organize themselves in order to taste a “Apthapi” (each one prepares and brings food in order to share it with the group).

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Tania

texts.en:
Tania is a member of the communal bank “Mujeres Perseverantes” (Persevering Women) and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Tania has a business selling Avon and Esika beauty products from her home. Tania plans to use this loan of 1500 Nuevos Soles to augment her stock of products.

Prior to her first loan from Manuela Ramos about two-and-a-half years ago, Tania had never worked. Thanks to her loans and the income generated from her business, Tania has been able to fix up her home with new wood panels for the interior. Eventually, she would like to purchase a glass show cabinet for her products.

Tania lives with her partner and their three children, a 15-year-old son and two daughters, aged 13 and 4. Tania’s partner has a job at the airport selling airline tickets. In this short video clip, Tania talks about her goal of moving forward with her business in order to ensure that her children can go to university.

loans.use: To buy additional stock.

loans.name: José Akouwa

texts.fr:
José Akouwa S.  est née le 30 juin 1987 au Togo, le pays ouest de Bénin.  Elle vivait au Bénin depuis près de huit ans.  José Akouwa mène un magasin où elle vend des mèches, des produits pour cheveux, des tissus, des produits cosmétiques. Son boutique est bien aménagée.  Elle a dû louer pour donner une bonne image à son activité et par conséquents posséder des clients crédibles.

Avec le crédit, José Akouwa voudrait acheter des mèches et des produits cosmétiques.  Elle sollicite un crédit pour pouvoir renforcer son stock et mieux maîtriser sa demande qui ne cesse de s'accroître.
texts.en:
José Akouwa S. was born on the 30th of June, 1987 in Togo, a country to the west of Benin. She has been living in Benin for about 8 years. José Akouwa operates a store where she sells hair pieces, hair products, fabrics and cosmetic products. Her kiosk is well maintained. She rented it specifically to present an attractive image of her business and as a consequence has attracted good quality clients. With this loan José Akouwa would like to buy hair pieces and cosmetic products. She is requesting the loan to build up her inventory and to better manage her ever increasing customer demands.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair pieces and cosmetic products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and supplies of working materials

loans.name: Harouna

texts.fr:
Monsieur Harouna Konaté est âgé de 34 ans et vit avec sa femme et ses enfants  dans le quartier Niébala de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Pour des raisons sociales (pauvreté des parents) Harouna abandonne l’école à l’âge de 12 ans. Étant l’ainé de sa famille, il décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus pour aider son père à subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, il décida d’apprendre le métier de tailleur auprès d’un de ses  ami. Avec une expérience de 15 ans, il a une maîtrise de son activité, et jouit d’une très grande popularité au niveau de la ville de Bougouni.
Dans le souci de satisfaire et fidéliser sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, il décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter une machine à broderie à Bamako (capitale du Mali)
Il est à son premier prêt individuel  avec l’institution. Sa clientèle est composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage améliorer son atelier pour  avoir davantage de clients et  contribuer aux dépenses de la famille tout en aidant son père.
texts.en:
Mr. Harouna Konaté, age 34, lives with his wife and children in the Niébala neigborhood of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Because of his parents' poverty, Harouna left school at the age of 12. As the eldest child, he decided to undertake income-generating activity to help his father support the family. After several unsuccessful ventures, he chose to learn the tailor's trade from a friend.

Fifteen years later, he has mastered his art, and enjoys great popularity with men and women clients in the city of Bougouni.

In order to satisfy and keep his growing clientele, Harouna is collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso to purchase an embroidery machine in Bamako, the capital of Mali. This is his first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. He expects to realise a monthly income benefit of 60 000 FCFA, which he will use to improve his workshop to accomodate more clients, as well as help his father by contributing to paying the family expenses.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of an Embroidery machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Only Jesus Group

texts.en:
Mercy (seated first from left) is a 45-year-old married mother of three children. She is a farmer and runs a provision store as well. Mercy is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Only Jesus’. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors or farmers. They work to support their spouses in providing for their families.

The group members buy their raw materials, wares or goods from other towns and sometimes from nearby communities, and sell in the local market square. Some of them trek to other towns to sell on their market days as well. The members have been in business for some time and have acquired experience in their businesses. It is in light of this that they are requesting a loan to procure more goods to expand their businesses.

The members of the group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Growing corn and manioc

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris originally comes from an indigenous Shipibo community and speaks Spanish as her second language. Doris and her husband run an auto parts shop on the main road that connects Pucallpa with the faraway capital Lima. The couple’s shop is located a few miles outside of Pucallpa. The family business is in Doris's name but is called “Autopartes Villa” (after the last name of Doris’s husband).

Doris is a member of the communal bank, “Mujeres Perseverantes” (Persevering Women) and has been working with Manuela Ramos for two-and-a-half years. She was one of the five founding members of her communal bank. Doris plans to use this loan of 2500 soles to buy more parts for the shop. Doris and her husband told me that their business is doing well. They are building up bit by bit. Although more capital would be useful to expand the amount of merchandise offered by the shop, Doris must be careful to only borrow as much as she can pay back. She has always been punctual with her loan payments.

Doris has one child, a five-year-old daughter who is in kindergarten. In this short video clip, Doris talks about her goal of expanding her business and increasing the variety of products available to customers.

loans.use: To augment the products available in the spare parts shop.

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Komi A. est un homme de 45 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants.il est conducteur de taxi à Avetonou, un village situé au sud-ouest du Togo. Komi souhaite avec ce crédit changer le moteur de sa voiture pour limiter les dépenses incessantes que lui cause sa voiture. Cette opportunité lui permettra de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Komi A. is a 45 year old man, he is married and the father of 3 children. He is a taxi driver in Avetonou, a town located in southwest Togo. Komi hopes that with this loan he will replace the motor of his car, in order to limit the never ending expenses that are caused by his car. This opportunity will enable him to respond better to the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replace the motor of his car

loans.name: Tersesa Luz

texts.es: La Señora Teresa Luz C. tiene 65 años. Es una madre una madre soltera. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. Por lo que su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 13 años que se dedica a este negocio. La ubicación de su humilde negocio es en su vivienda. La mayoría de sus compras las realiza en el mercado. Ella tiene sus clientes a quienes  compra las golosinas entre otras cosas, Teresa es una mujer muy agradable y por medio de este negocio ha podido sobrevivir y sufragar los gastos. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos y productos diarios. El deseo de Teresa es brindar una estabilidad económica a su familia.
texts.en:
Teresa Luz C. is 65 years old. She is a single mother. She has 2 children under her care. She runs a small general store. She has dedicated herself to this business for over 13 years. Her humble business is located in her home. She does most of her shopping at the market. She has clients who buy candies amongst other things. Teresa is a very pleasant woman and through this business he has been able to survive and cover her expenses. The loan will be used as work capital to purchase candies, basic grains, and other every day products. Teresa’s dream is to offer her family financial stability.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital (to purchase candies, basic grains, and other every day products).

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mohamed Traoré est âgé  de 29 ans et vit avec  son enfant et son épouse  chez son père  à Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
Après l’école coranique, Mohamed décida d’aller tenter sa chance en dehors du Mali, précisément en république de Côte d’Ivoire à la recherche d’une vie meilleure.
Ses ambutions n’ont pas été réalisées, il décida de retourner à Bougouni auprès de son père pour apprendre le commerce notamment la vente des articles de fête etc. Avec une expérience de 10 ans, Mohamed Traoré maîtrise bien son activité et est très sollicité.
Afin  de  renforcer ses activités, Monsieur Mohamed décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt, pour acheter des articles de fête, tissus....
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali), auprès des grossistes et vend  ses articles à une clientèle composée  de toutes les catégories sociales. 
Les fêtes réligieuses et les grandes cérémonies (baptêmes, mariages, circoncisions, anniversaires etc) sont les périodes où les ventes de ses articles sont intenses.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Mohamed Traoré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA.
Son  ambition est dans les années à venir  d’agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Mohamed Traoré, age 29, lives with his child and his wife at his father's in Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), in the Hérémakono Nord neighborhood. After Koranic school, Mohamed decided to try his luck outside Mali, in the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire, in search of a better life.

His ambitions did not fulfill, and so he decided to come back to his father in Bougouni, to learn the business of selling party items. With 10 years of experience, Mohamed Traoré now masters this business and is in high demand.

In order to bolster his business, Mohamed decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, from which he is seeking his first loan to buy party items, fabrics, ... He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali), and sells his products to a clientele comprising people of all social categories.

Religous holidays and ceremonies (baptisms, weddings, circumcisions, birthdays, ...) are the periods where the sales are very high. With this loan, Mr. Mohamed Traoré counts on turning a monthly profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 140). He ambitions to expand his store in the coming years.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell party supplies and fabrics

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
Thủy Nguyễn Thị (535040967) is a 29 year-old woman living in the town of Ý Yên. Married with three school-aged children, Thủy owns and operates a manufacturing business whose main source of income comes from manufacturing and selling wood products to local businesses and community members. Thủy has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 3900000 VND a month.

In 2004, Thủy joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8000000 VND from TYM Fund that was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products, Thuy is now requesting a new loan of 16000000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her sixth loan from TYM Fund, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her operation.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.
